translated: “ And furthermore, the great ocean has but one taste—the taste of salt.

analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave imasmin dhamma vinaye anupubba sikkhā anupubba kiriyā anupubba paṭipadā na āyatakena iva aññā paṭivedhaḥ

translated: That in this Dhamma and Discipline there is gradual training, gradual practice, and gradual progress, and not instantaneous knowledge and seeing:

analyzed: bhikkhave imasmin dhamma vinaye paṭhamaḥ acchariyaḥ abbhutaḥ dhammaḥ yam disvā disvā bhikkhū imasmin dhamma vinaye abhiramanti
translated: This is the first extraordinary thing, bhikkhus, that the bhikkhus see on this side of existence, on seeing which they delight in this Dhamma and Discipline.

translated: “Just as the great ocean has a uniform salinity,🔽so too, in this Dhamma and Discipline, the training and the practice are uniform and the goal is taught as the goal of the one who has trained.

original: Yampi, bhikkhave, mayā mama sāvakānaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ paññattaṁ, taṁ mama sāvakā jīvitahetupi nātikkamanti—

original: ayaṁ, bhikkhave, imasmiṁ dhammavinaye dutiyo acchariyo abbhuto dhammo, yaṁ disvā disvā bhikkhū imasmiṁ dhammavinaye abhiramanti.

translated: This is the second amazing & astounding quality of this Dhamma & Vinaya because of which, having seen it, the monks delight in this Dhamma & Vinaya.

translated: “And furthermore, the ocean doesn’t tolerate a dead body. If there is a dead body in the ocean, the ocean quickly hurls it up onto dry land.

original: avassuto kasambujāto, na tena saṅgho saṁvasati, khippameva naṁ sannipatitvā ukkhipati,

original: kiñcāpi kho so hoti majjhe bhikkhusaṅghassa nisinno. Atha kho so ārakāva saṅghamhā, saṅgho ca tena.

analyzed: a ssamaṇaḥ samaṇa paṭiññaḥ a brahmacārī brahmacāri paṭiññaḥ antopūti avassutaḥ kasambu jātaḥ  na tena saṅghaḥ savasati khippam eva nam sannipatitvā ukkhipati kiñca api kho so hoti
translated: not an ascetic, though making it known he is an ascetic, not living the spiritual life, though making it known he is, rotten inside, lustful, defiled, and greedy,🔽the Sangha doesn’t live with him. It quickly gathers and ejects him. Even if he’s sitting in the midst of the Sangha,

translated: “Just as the great ocean has a single taste, the taste of salt,

translated: I stop the observance-day ceremony for the person so-and-so. The observance-day ceremony should not be done in his presence.’ The observance-day ceremony is stopped in this way.”

analyzed: bhūtam idam attā ādāna naḥ abhūtanti tena upāli bhikkhunā uttari
translated: ‘This self-mortification is true, not false,’ he should review it further:

analyzed: yam kho aham imam attā ādānam ādātu kāmaḥ attha sañhitam nu kho idam attā ādānam udāhu no ti

original: Sace, upāli, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṁ jānāti—

translated: If, on reviewing it, he knows:

original: ‘anatthasañhitaṁ idaṁ attādānaṁ, no atthasañhitan’ti, na taṁ, upāli, attādānaṁ ādātabbaṁ.
analyzed: anattha sañhitam idam attādāna no attha sañhitam ti na te upāli attādānam ādātabba
translated: ‘This legal procedure of self-confession is connected with harm, not with benefit,’ then that legal procedure of self-confession should not be done.

original: Sace panupāli, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṁ jānāti—
analyzed: sace panupāli bhikkhu paccavekkhamānaḥ evam jānāti
translated: If, when reviewing, a monk knows,

original: ‘atthasañhitaṁ idaṁ attādānaṁ, no anatthasañhitan’ti, tenupāli, bhikkhunā uttari paccavekkhitabbaṁ—
analyzed: attha sañhitam idam attā ādāna no anattha sañhitam ti tena upāli bhikkhunā uttari
translated: ‘This legal procedure of self-confession is connected with benefit, not with harm,’ he should review further,

original: ‘imaṁ kho ahaṁ attādānaṁ ādiyamāno labhissāmi sandiṭṭhe sambhatte bhikkhū dhammato vinayato pakkhe udāhu no’ti?
analyzed: imam kho aham attā ādānam ādiyamānaḥ labhissāmi sandiṭṭhe sambhatte bhikkhū dhammataḥ vinayataḥ pakkhe udāhu no ti
translated: ‘If I do this legal procedure of self-confession, will I get the support of other monks who are knowledgeable about the Teaching and the training?’

original: Sace, upāli, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṁ jānāti—
analyzed: sace upāli bhikkhu paccavekkhamānaḥ evam jānāti

analyzed: imam kho aham attā ādānam ādiyamānaḥ na labhissāmi sandiṭṭhe sambhatte bhikkhū dhammataḥ vinayataḥ pakkheti na te upāli attā ādānam ādātabba
translated: ‘If I do this legal procedure of self-confession, I won’t get the support of other monks who are knowledgeable about the Teaching and the training,’ then that legal procedure of self-confession should not be done.

original: Sace panupāli, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṁ jānāti—
analyzed: sace panupāli bhikkhu paccavekkhamānaḥ evam jānāti
translated: If, when reviewing, he knows,

original: ‘imaṁ kho ahaṁ attādānaṁ ādiyamāno labhissāmi sandiṭṭhe sambhatte bhikkhū dhammato vinayato pakkhe’ti, tenupāli, bhikkhunā uttari paccavekkhitabbaṁ—
analyzed: imam kho aham attā ādānam ādiyamānaḥ labhissāmi sandiṭṭhe sambhatte bhikkhū dhammataḥ vinayataḥ pakkheti tena upāli bhikkhunā uttari paccavekkhitabba
translated: ‘If I take this legal procedure of information against them, I’ll get the support of other monks who are just like me in regard to the Teaching and the Monastic Law.’

original: ‘imaṁ kho me attādānaṁ ādiyato bhavissati saṅghassa tatonidānaṁ bhaṇḍanaṁ kalaho viggaho vivādo saṅghabhedo saṅgharāji saṅghavavatthānaṁ saṅghanānākaraṇaṁ udāhu no’ti?

translated: ‘If I take this legal procedure of information against them, will it lead to a dispute in the Sangha, a legal issue, a schism, a fracture, or a split in the Sangha?’

original: Sace upāli, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṁ jānāti—

translated: If, Upāli, a monk who is reviewing the matter knows,

analyzed: imam kho me attā ādānam ādiyataḥ bhavissati saṅghassa tatonidānam bhaṇḍanam kalahaḥ

analyzed: viggahaḥ vivādaḥ saṅgha bhedaḥ saṅgha rāji saṅgha vavatthānam saṅgha nānākaraṇanti na  te upāli attā ādānam ādātabba
translated: then he shouldn’t take it.

original: Sace panupāli, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṁ jānāti—

translated: But if he knows,

original: ‘imaṁ kho me attādānaṁ ādiyato na bhavissati saṅghassa tatonidānaṁ bhaṇḍanaṁ kalaho
analyzed: imam kho me attā ādānam ādiyataḥ na bhavissati saṅghassa tatonidānam bhaṇḍanam kalahaḥ
translated: ‘If I take this legal procedure of information against them, it won’t lead to a dispute in the Sangha, a legal issue,

analyzed: viggahaḥ vivādaḥ saṅgha bhedaḥ saṅgha rāji saṅgha vavatthānam saṅgha nānākaraṇan ti ādātabba

original: taṁ, upāli, attādānaṁ.
analyzed: te upāli attā ādāna
translated: You should accept it.

original: Evaṁ pañcaṅgasamannāgataṁ kho, upāli, attādānaṁ ādinnaṁ, pacchāpi avippaṭisārakaraṁ bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: evam pañcaṅga samannāgatam kho upāli attā ādānam ādinna pacchā api a vippaṭisāra karam bhavissati iti
translated: If you accept it in this way, you won’t have any regrets later.”

original: 8. Codakenapaccavekkhitabbadhamma
analyzed: codakena paccavekkhitabba dhamma
translated: The qualities to be reflected upon by the one who accuses

original: “Codakena, bhante, bhikkhunā paraṁ codetukāmena kati dhamme ajjhattaṁ paccavekkhitvā paro codetabbo”ti?
analyzed: codakena bhante bhikkhunā param codetu kāmena kati dhamme ajjhattam paccavekkhitvā paraḥ codetabbo ti
translated: “Sir, when a monk is accusing another, how many qualities should he reflect on in himself?”

original: “Codakena, upāli, bhikkhunā paraṁ codetukāmena pañca dhamme ajjhattaṁ paccavekkhitvā paro codetabbo.🔽Codakena, upāli, bhikkhunā paraṁ codetukāmena evaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ—
analyzed: codakena upāli bhikkhunā param codetu kāmena pañca dhamme ajjhattam paccavekkhitvā paraḥ codetabbo  codakena upāli bhikkhunā param codetu kāmena evam paccavekkhitabba
translated: “When a monk is accusing another, he should reflect on five qualities in himself:

original: ‘parisuddhakāyasamācāro nu khomhi, parisuddhenamhi kāyasamācārena samannāgato—acchiddena appaṭimaṁsena? Saṁvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no’ti?
analyzed: parisuddha kāya samācāraḥ nu khomhi kāya samācārena samannāgataḥ acchiddena appaṭimasena sa vijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no ti
translated: ‘Am I pure in bodily conduct? Do I have bodily conduct that’s clean and without flaw? Is this quality found in me or not?’

original: No ce, upāli, bhikkhu parisuddhakāyasamācāro hoti, parisuddhena kāyasamācārena samannāgato—acchiddena appaṭimaṁsena, tassa bhavanti vattāro—
analyzed: no ce upāli bhikkhu parisuddha kāya samācāraḥ hoti parisuddhena kāya samācārena samannāgata uacchiddena appaṭimasena tassa bhavanti vattāro
translated: If a monk is impure in bodily conduct, and he does not have pure bodily conduct that is clean and open, then those who accuse him will say,

original: ‘iṅgha tāva āyasmā kāyikaṁ sikkhassū’ti. Itissa bhavanti vattāro.
analyzed: iṅgha tāva āyasmai kāyikam sikkhassu iti itissa bhavanti vattāraḥ
translated: ‘First, Venerable, you should train the body.’

original: Puna caparaṁ, upāli, codakena bhikkhunā paraṁ codetukāmena evaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ—
analyzed: puna caparaḥ upāli codakena bhikkhunā param codetu kāmena evam paccavekkhitabba
translated: ‘And further, Upāli, one who accuses another should first review this:

original: ‘parisuddhavacīsamācāro nu khomhi, parisuddhenamhi vacīsamācārena samannāgato—acchiddena appaṭimaṁsena? Saṁvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no’ti?
analyzed: parisuddha vacī samācāraḥ nu kho mhi vacī samācārena samannāgataḥ uacchiddena appaṭimasena savijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no ti
translated: “Am I pure in verbal conduct, do I have pure verbal conduct that is clean and open? Is this quality found in me or not?”

original: No ce, upāli, bhikkhu parisuddhavacīsamācāro hoti, parisuddhena vacīsamācārena samannāgato—
analyzed: no ce upāli bhikkhu parisuddha vacī samācāraḥ hoti parisuddhena vacī samācārena samannāgataḥ
translated: If a monk is impure in verbal conduct, and he does not have pure verbal conduct that is clean and open,

original: acchiddena appaṭimaṁsena, tassa bhavanti vattāro—
analyzed: acchiddena appaṭimasena tassa bhavanti vattāro
translated: then those who accuse him will say,

original: ‘iṅgha tāva āyasmā vācasikaṁ sikkhassū’ti. Itissa bhavanti vattāro.
analyzed: iṅgha tāva āyasmai vācasikam sikkhassu iti itissa bhavanti vattāraḥ
translated: ‘First, Venerable, you should train the speech.’

original: Puna caparaṁ, upāli, codakena bhikkhunā paraṁ codetukāmena evaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ—
analyzed: puna caparaḥ upāli codakena bhikkhunā param codetu kāmena evam paccavekkhitabba
translated: “And further, Upāli, a monk who is accusing another should reflect thus:

original: ‘mettaṁ nu kho me cittaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ sabrahmacārīsu anāghātaṁ, saṁvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no’ti?
analyzed: mettam nu kho me cittam paccupaṭṭhitam sabrahmacārīsu anāghāta sa vijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no ti
translated: ‘Is my mind free from anger towards my fellow monastics, is it free from ill will, is it free from anger? Is this quality found in me or not?’

original: No ce, upāli, bhikkhuno mettacittaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu anāghātaṁ, tassa bhavanti vattāro—
analyzed: no ce upāli bhikkhuno metta cittam paccupaṭṭhitam hoti sabrahmacārīsu anāghāta tassa bhavanti vattāro
translated: If a monk’s mind is not free from anger towards his fellow monastics, there will be those who say,

original: ‘iṅgha tāva āyasmā sabrahmacārīsu mettacittaṁ upaṭṭhāpehī’ti. Itissa bhavanti vattāro.
analyzed: tāva āyasmā sabrahmacārīsu metta cittam upaṭṭhāpehi iti itissa bhavanti vattāro
translated: ‘First, reverend Sir, you should make your mind free from anger towards your fellow monastics.’ There will be those who say this.

original: Puna caparaṁ, upāli, codakena bhikkhunā paraṁ codetukāmena evaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ—🔽‘bahussuto nu khomhi, sutadharo, sutasannicayo? Ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā
analyzed: puna caparaḥ upāli codakena bhikkhunā param codetu kāmena evam paccavekkhitabba  bahu sutaḥ nu kho mhi suta dharaḥ suta sannicayaḥ ye te dhammāḥ ādi kalyāṇāḥ majjhe kalyāṇāḥ
translated: “And further, Upāli, a monk who is accusing another should reflect thus:

original: pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ
analyzed: pariyosāna kalyāṇā sa attham sa byañjanam kevala paripuṇṇam parisuddham
translated: ‘Am I learned, do I hold the tradition, do I possess a good voice, am I skilled in what should be learnt, do I remember and keep what I have learnt? Are those dharmas which are in the beginning, middle, and end,🔽good, well-proclaimed, leading to welfare, to be directly experienced by the wise ones for themselves,

original: abhivadanti, tathārūpā me dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā
analyzed: abhivadanti tathārūpāḥ me dhammāḥ bahu sutāḥ honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasā anupekkhitā
translated: and I’ve learned them well, remembered them, discussed them, and examined them well with my wisdom,

original: diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā? Saṁvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no’ti?
analyzed: diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā savijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no ti
translated: do I possess this quality or not?’🔽If he’s not learned, then he should say so.

original: No ce, upāli, bhikkhu bahussuto hoti, sutadharo, sutasannicayo; ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā
analyzed: no ce upāli bhikkhu bahu ssutaḥ hoti suta dharaḥ suta sannicayaḥ ye te dhammāḥ ādi kalyāṇā
translated: If he’s learned, but he hasn’t learned the teachings that are good in the beginning,

original: majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ🔽brahmacariyaṁ abhivadanti, tathārūpassa dhammā na bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā🔽manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā, tassa bhavanti vattāro—
analyzed: majjhe kalyāṇā pariyosāna kalyāṇā sa attham sa byañjanam kevala paripuṇṇam parisuddha  brahmacariyam abhivadanti tathārūpassa dhammā na bahu ssutāḥ honti dhātā vacasā paricitā  manasā an upekkhitā diṭṭhiyā su paṭividdhā tassa bhavanti vattāro
translated: good in the middle, and good in the end, that have a true goal and are well articulated, and that set out the perfectly complete and pure spiritual life,🔽then he should say so.

original: ‘iṅgha tāva āyasmā āgamaṁ pariyāpuṇassū’ti. Itissa bhavanti vattāro.
analyzed: tāva āyasmai āgamam pariyāpuṇassu iti itissa bhavanti vattāraḥ
translated: And he’ll be criticized by others.

original: Puna caparaṁ, upāli, codakena bhikkhunā paraṁ codetukāmena evaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ—
analyzed: puna caparaḥ upāli codakena bhikkhunā param codetu kāmena evam paccavekkhitabba
translated: And further, Upāli, a monk who’s accusing another should reflect on himself in this way:

original: ‘ubhayāni kho me pātimokkhāni vitthārena svāgatāni honti, suvibhattāni, suppavattīni, suvinicchitāni, suttaso, anubyañjanaso? Saṁvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no’ti?🔽No ce, upāli, bhikkhuno ubhayāni pātimokkhāni vitthārena svāgatāni honti, suvibhattāni,
analyzed: ubhayāni kho me pātimokkhāni vitthārena svāgatāni honti su vibhattāni suppavattīni su vinicchitāni suttaso anubyañjanaso sa vijjati nu kho me eso dhammaḥ udāhu no ti  no ce upāli bhikkhunaḥ ubhayāni pātimokkhāni vitthārena svāgatāni honti su vibhattāni
translated: ‘Have I learned both Monastic Codes well, in detail, and analyzed the rules, their origins, the way to resolve the legal issues, and the methods for settling them? Do I have this quality or not?’

original: suppavattīni, suvinicchitāni, suttaso, anubyañjanaso, ‘idaṁ panāvuso, kattha vuttaṁ
analyzed: su pavattīni su vinicchitāni idam pana āvuso kattha
translated: If he hasn’t learned both Monastic Codes well, in detail, and analyzed the rules, their origins, the way to resolve the legal issues, and the methods for settling them,

original: bhagavatā’ti, iti puṭṭho na sampāyati, tassa bhavanti vattāro—
analyzed: bhagavatā ati iti puṭṭhaḥ na sampāyati tassa bhavanti vattāraḥ
translated: and if, when asked, ‘Where was that said?’ he can’t quote the exact location,🔽then he’s to be told,

original: ‘iṅgha tāva āyasmā vinayaṁ pariyāpuṇassū’ti. Itissa bhavanti vattāro.
analyzed: tāva āyasmai vinayam pariyāpuṇassu iti itissa bhavanti vattāraḥ
translated: ‘First learn the Monastic Law.’

original: Codakenupāli, bhikkhunā paraṁ codetukāmena ime pañca dhamme ajjhattaṁ paccavekkhitvā paro codetabbo”ti.
analyzed: codakena upāli bhikkhunā param codetu kāmena ime pañca dhamme ajjhattam paccavekkhitvā paraḥ codetabbo ti
translated: When accusing another, one should review these five qualities in oneself.”

original: 9. Codakenaupaṭṭhāpetabbadhamma
analyzed: ca udakena upaṭṭhāpetabba dhamma
translated: The qualities of one who should be attended on

original: “Codakena, bhante, bhikkhunā paraṁ codetukāmena kati dhamme ajjhattaṁ upaṭṭhāpetvā paro codetabbo”ti?
analyzed: codakena bhante bhikkhunā param codetu kāmena kati dhamme ajjhattam upaṭṭhāpetvā paraḥ codetabbo ti
translated: “When a monk is accusing another, how many qualities should he have to accuse the other?”

original: “Codakenupāli, bhikkhunā paraṁ codetukāmena pañca dhamme ajjhattaṁ upaṭṭhāpetvā paro codetabbo—🔽kālena vakkhāmi, no akālena;
analyzed: codakena upāli bhikkhunā param codetu kāmena pañca dhamme ajjhattam upaṭṭhāpetvā paraḥ codetabbo  kālena vakkhāmi no akālena
translated: “When a monk is accusing another, he should have five qualities:

original: bhūtena vakkhāmi, no abhūtena;🔽saṇhena vakkhāmi, no pharusena;
analyzed: bhūtena vakkhāmi no abhūtena  saṇhena vakkhāmi no pharusena
translated: he should speak at an appropriate time, not at an inappropriate time;🔽he should speak truthfully, not falsely;🔽he should speak gently, not harshly;

original: atthasaṁhitena vakkhāmi, no anatthasaṁhitena;
analyzed: attha sahitena vakkhāmi no anattha sahitena
translated: he should speak beneficially, not unbeneficially;

original: mettacitto vakkhāmi, no dosantaroti.
analyzed: metta cittaḥ vakkhāmi naḥ dosantaro ti
translated: he should speak with a mind of good will, not with internal ill will.

original: Codakenupāli, bhikkhunā paraṁ codetukāmena ime pañca dhamme ajjhattaṁ upaṭṭhāpetvā paro codetabbo”ti.
analyzed: codakena upāli bhikkhunā param codetu kāmena ime pañca dhamme ajjhattam upaṭṭhāpetvā paraḥ codetabbo ti
translated: When a monk is accusing another, he should have these five qualities.”

original: 10. Codakacuditakapaṭisaṁyuttakathā
analyzed: codaka cuditaka paṭisayutta kathā
translated: . The discussion with Upāli on the one who accuses and the accused

original: “Adhammacodakassa, bhante, bhikkhuno katihākārehi vippaṭisāro upadahātabbo”ti?
analyzed: adhamma codakassa bhante bhikkhuno kati hākārehi vippaṭisāraḥ upadahātabbaḥ ti
translated: “When a monk is accusing another illegitimately, in how many ways should he be pressed to make him stop?”

original: “Adhammacodakassa, upāli, bhikkhuno pañcahākārehi vippaṭisāro upadahātabbo—
analyzed: adhamma codakassa upāli bhikkhuno pañcahā ākārehi vippaṭisāraḥ upadahātabbaḥ
translated: “When a monk is accusing another illegitimately, he should be pressed in five ways:

original: akālenāyasmā codesi, no kālena, alaṁ te vippaṭisārāya;
analyzed: akālena ayasmā codesi no kālena alam te vippaṭisārāya
translated: You accused him at the wrong time, not the right time. You shouldn’t reproach him for that.

original: abhūtenāyasmā codesi, no bhūtena, alaṁ te vippaṭisārāya;🔽pharusenāyasmā codesi, no saṇhena, alaṁ te vippaṭisārāya;
analyzed: abhūtena ayasmā codesi no bhūtena alam te vippaṭisārāya  pharusena ayasmā codesi no saṇhena alam te vippaṭisārāya
translated: You accused him falsely, not truthfully. You shouldn’t reproach him for that.🔽You accused him harshly, not gently. You shouldn’t reproach him for that.

original: anatthasaṁhitenāyasmā codesi, no atthasaṁhitena, alaṁ te vippaṭisārāya;
analyzed: anattha sahitena ayasmā codesi no attha sahitena alam te vippaṭisārāya
translated: You accused him unbeneficially, not beneficially. You shouldn’t reproach him for that.

original: dosantaro āyasmā codesi, no mettacitto, alaṁ te vippaṭisārāyāti.
analyzed: dosantaro codesi no metta cittaḥ alam te vippaṭisārāya ati
